timeline.message: Avoid using CL to load test class. Use Description getTestClass accessor instead.
Use spanNameForMethod to calculate test resourceName
Exclude JUnit4 testInheritance classes to be executed during dd-java-agent build lifecycle
service() is based on a field in TestDecorator
Use testSuite and testName from Description to calculate resourceName

timeline.bodyText: So I thought that setting the TEST_STATUS to TEST_PASS here in onTestStart seemed a bit premature,  shouldn't that be done in onTestFinish? But after reading the instrumentation, it seems that onTestFinish is called for all tests even if it is a failure. Would be nice with some short comments explaining which method gets called when. And yes most of the other decorators are missing this type of information which I think is a shame.

replies.author: drodriguezhdez

timeline.bodyText: I'm curious if using a RunListener would suffice instead of resorting to instrumentation.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: I think we'd need to instrument the org.junit.runner.Runner.run(RunNotifier runNotifier) method to add our custom "Trace" RunListener in that case. That Runner is an abstract class, so bytecode manipulation would be affected in several classes if I'm not wrong. That's why I preferred to instrument a single point, the class RunNotifier.
replies.author: drodriguezhdez

timeline.bodyText:
This ends up repeating the annotation detection of JUnit.
If the RunListener is sufficient, we can avoid that altogether.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: I'm confused when you say "repeating the annotation detection of JUnit`. Can you elaborate?
replies.author: drodriguezhdez

replies.bodyText:
Generally, I think when there is a callback API we should try to use it.
That may not always work if the callback API doesn't provide access to all the information that we want, but we should try.
So I'd like to know what we're doing here that cannot be done with a RunListener.
Because this code ends up repeating the @Test & @Ignore detection rules that already exist inside of JUnit.
I'd prefer not to repeat that logic (and potentially miss edge cases) unless we have good reason to do so.
replies.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText:
I think we can obtain same information using both RunNotifier or RunListener, cause RunNotifier invokes every RunListener configured in the Runner.
The reason of using directly RunNotifier is in this comment, but I can change the implementation to create our own RunListener and add it to the runner using instrumentation if we feel more comfortable with that approach.
The logic in that new RunListener would be exactly the same that we use in the RunNotifier instrumentation nowadays.
replies.author: drodriguezhdez
